awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Integrating Electronic and Visual Signals for Accurate Localization
awd_abstract_narration:
Nowadays, an increasing number of objects can be represented by their wireless electronic identifiers. For examples, people can be recognized by their cellular phones' or laptops' MAC addresses and products can be identified by their RFID numbers. Localizing objects with electronic identifiers is more and more important as our society is becoming increasingly "digitalized". However, traditional wireless localization techniques cannot meet the rapidly mounting requirements of accurate and cost-effective localization. Some of them need expensive hardware to achieve high accuracy, which is impractical for massive deployments, while others such as WiFi RSSI based localization are inaccurate and not robust to environmental noise. 

This project designs a novel localization methodology called EVLoc. In EVLoc, visual signals (V signals) are used to improve the accuracy of electronic localization, as the accuracy of visual localization is around 0.1-0.5 meter. This technique fully leverages V signals' high accuracy and the pervasiveness of electronic signals (E signals). The project conducts three main research tasks: (1) perform object localization given complete and distinct E and V signals, (2) perform object localization in practical settings when the E and V signals are not complete and distinct, and (3) implement the E-V approach to validate its accuracy and efficacy. This pioneering research develops a transformative approach that integrates E and V signals for accurate localization. The approach can be applied to many emerging applications such as epidemic control and tracking of elderly people, children, and those exhibiting at-risk behaviors for healthcare purposes.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to achieve accurate localization of objects and human beings using electronic and visual signal integrated technologies. The specific objectives are to design electronic and visual signal integrated algorithms and protocols for accurate detection and localization of objects and human beings in both theoretical and practical settings (such as time and deployment constraints and interference etc.). Our approach has been to be able to jointly exploit and explore opportunities of electronic and visual signals, as well as other sensing signals such as motion and acoustics ones, to make our localization systems more cost-effective and efficient.

This project produced several key outcomes. They can be summarized into six thrusts: (1) EV-Loc for accurate non-human object localization: Our EV-Loc technique fully leverages visual signals’ high accuracy and electronic signals’ pervasiveness. To effectively couple these two signals, we designed an E-V match engine to ?nd the correspondence between an object’s electronic identi?er and its visual appearance. (2) EV-Human for accurate human localization: We investigated using video cameras to help estimate human body’s interference on mobile device’s signals. We combined human orientation detection and human/phone/AP relative position inference estimation to better measure how a human blocks or re?ects wireless signals. (3) EV-Sounding for visual assisted electronic channel sounding for accurate localization: we designed EV-Sounding, a novel technique for timely, high-resolution channel sounding, based on electronic and visual signals. By leveraging the visualized multipath information and our linear regression methodology, we successfully integrated electronic and visual signals and accurately recovered the channel impulse response. (4) EV-Verification for Human Recognition: we integrated E and V signals for verification of a person in a security environment.   Once the E signal of a person is received, we use a video-based face recognition algorithm based on a sequentially and recursively sampling and updating scheme. (5) VM-Tracking for human tracking: We designed an appearance-free tracking algorithm based on the physical location proximity and motion continuity. It helped us avoid unnecessary and intensive computation on visual appearance comparisons, and is a promising mechanism to benefit all tracking algorithms.  (6) Flash-Loc for human-cooperative accurate localization: We designed Flash-Loc, an accurate indoor localization system leveraging flashes of light to localize people carrying mobile phones in areas with deployed surveillance cameras. We further developed a system in which Flash-Loc cooperates with fingerprinting and dead reckoning for accurate human localization.

The project produced many journal and conference publications, involving faculty and student participants from two PIs’ research groups. The results have been listed and published on http://web.cse.ohio-state.edu/~xuan/RP/CNS1218876.htm. The project also provided research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including students from underrepresented groups.
